Description: Egyptian terracotta female figure wearing festival wreath headdress with two lotus buds. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. White coating, with orange-pink paint traces. Orange-brown Nile silt fabric.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Same headdress represented on another example from Naukratis (Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology NA557). Similar Roman style example from Egypt has been dated to the 2nd century AD (Bayer-Niemeier 1988, pl.69.3, no.388). However a good parallel from Athribis (Tell Atrib) is dated to the 3rd century BC (Szmańska 2005, no. 194). Bayer-Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten. Melsungen. Szymańska, H. 2005, Terres cuites d’Athribis, Turnhout.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.442) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Jean de Mot
